documents.document: 2: If I found myself living in the BC world, struggling with my robes and I saw someone walking about in trousers, I would've asked them, 'Hey, what are those? Where'd you get them?'

Given trousers were invented between the 10th and 13th centuries BC, I've long wondered why they took so long to establish themselves globally. Sure, travel was limited back then but you'd have still had migrants turning up in trousers. >

Everywhere you look, there were a catalogue of failures that led to my giving myself lifelong dread of The Count.

> Also complicit in my reading Bram Stoker's Count at such a young age was my cousin @Textman1966. It was his library book I'd borrowed. He was fourteen. Old enough to have known an 8-year-old shouldn't be reading a vampire book.

Sure, my parents were Spanish. They couldn't understand English but it was clear from the vampire on the book's cover, that I was reading something I shouldn't be reading at just 8 years of age. A vampire is a vampire in any language. >
Big mistake to read Bram Stoker's book, unabridged, at just 8-years-old. Such is my fear of The Count, to this day I don't like the combination of black with a red lining, like his cape.
Nine to five, cancer and Bram Stoker's Count, my three biggest fears.
